thread.title: Student/professor romances permitted under new policy
thread.title_full: Student/professor romances permitted under new policy | Albuquerque Journal News

author: Maggie Shepard / Journal Staff Writer
title: Student/professor romances permitted under new policy
text:
Until 2014, an ethics statement about maintaining an appropriate work and academic environment was a guide for all University of New Mexico employees considering a relationship with a student or boss, colleague or subordinate.
But, in 2014, in the middle of an investigation into a complaint stemming from the contentious breakup between music professor Bradley Ellingboe and UNM Foundation employee Samantha Starr, the university created a new policy warning against – but not banning – consensual relationships between teachers and professors or bosses and subordinates.
And it requires that such relationships be reported to a supervisor.
Professors at UNM and across the nation say that type of policy strikes an appropriate balance between an overbearing school and an unsafe classroom environment.
Starr, who was not a subordinate or superior to Ellingboe, says the policy doesn’t go far enough to protect students.
“UNM’s policy is much less comprehensive than that of many other institutions of higher learning,” she said in a statement.
Harvard this year joined the University of California, Yale and several other prominent universities in banning outright relationships between teachers and students, according to the schools and news reports.
“Many institutions of higher learning … have realized that students are potentially vulnerable to sexual exploitation by faculty in a variety of ways,” Starr said. “These institutions have developed much more comprehensive policies that have much higher standards of conduct for faculty, and thus provide much greater levels of protection against student exploitation.”
But longtime professor Richard Holder, who served as president of the Faculty Senate while the school created the policy in 2014, said most professors felt the policy went far enough to protect students without micromanaging adults’ private lives, though he said some faculty wanted a stricter policy and some wanted no policy.
“Most faculty would agree that, when there is a romantic liaison that crosses the boundaries of academic power, then that’s a real problem,” he said. “Most of our students are consenting adults and it’s not unusual for adults to have relationships with people they work with.”
Holder said supervisors have at times been alerted to such relationships and, as an example, found alternative classes for a student to enroll in or an additional professor to administer a final grade.
The policy requires an alert to a supervisor “to manage the actual or perceived conflicts of interest caused by the relationships and to mitigate adverse effects on third parties.”
“The University normally has no interest in romantic or sexual consensual relationships involving members of the campus community. However, when such relationships occur in educational or supervisory contexts, they can present serious ethical concerns and compromise the University’s academic and work environment, in part due to an inherent power differential between the parties,” the policy reads.
“The relationships can lead to charges of sexual harassment and exploitation, especially when the relationships end, or cause third parties to have concerns about undue advantage or restricted opportunities.”
New Mexico State University’s policy “strongly discourages consensual relationships” as they can “contain the potential for exploitation” of the student or employee. Adults in these relationships are instructed to alert a supervisor to structure grading or responsibility plans to avoid conflict of interest.
Central New Mexico Community College’s policy prohibits relationships between employees with authority and their subordinates, including teachers with students, coaches with players and bosses with staff.
The American Association of University Professors, however, says banning relationships isn’t practical or the preferred approach. The group suggests schools adopt a policy similar to UNM’s that strongly warns against such relationships and requires some sort of alert, according to the group’s policy suggestions website.
